snippet: Thousands of former Yugoslavians may have settled in America, but echoes of the war still resound.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Kenan Trebincevic describes how the deep resentment inspired by ethnic conflict in the former Yugoslavia persists, even in the immigrant community in Queens, NYC. Drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: I'M a 31-year-old physical therapist living in Astoria, Queens, an American citizen more into ''Seinfeld'' reruns than bloodthirsty revenge. And yet, 20 years after the start of the Bosnian war that exiled my Muslim family, I still hesitated to buy my lamb prsuta from my neighborhood's Serbian butcher, until I learned he had been here 30 years. So he couldn't have been the soldier with the AK-47 who took my father and brother to the concentration camp. I'm one of over 10,000 ex-Yugoslavians in Queens. I have my hair cut by my old countryman Gigi and eat cevapi at the Old Bridge (owned by a Sarajevan also named Kenan). The most ambitious place I've frequented around here was Marshall, a Yugoslavia-themed restaurant and lounge meant to help my generation forget about the ethnic hatreds that tore my old country apart. Gigi, who in addition to the hair salon runs a neighborhood wine bar, opened Marshall in 2009. When my brother, Eldin, and I first went there that December, it was like walking back into our childhood, to the home I was forced to flee at age 13. The D.J. was blasting ''Is Sarajevo Where It Once Was,'' by Dino Merlin, the famous Bosniak pop artist. Pictures of the Yugoslavian soccer team hung on the walls.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY
